data.title: 'An extraordinary man': director Nigel Cole remembers late actor Bob Hoskins
data.meta_description: With his thick Cockney accent and stout frame, British character actor Bob Hoskins was probably best known for his tough-guy roles, many of which either revealed a soft heart or an even harder interior. Nigel Cole, who directed Hoskins in 2010's acclaimed film Made in Dagenham remembers him as "incredibly warm" and "lovely" to work with. Hoskins died of pneumonia...
data.text:
"I could not be more grateful to his generosity of spirit, and his talent, and just what an extraordinary man he was," Mr. Cole tells Carol.

Mr. Hoskins' breakthrough role was in the 1980 thriller The Long Good Friday, where he played a British gangster. In 1986, he was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Actor in Neil Jordan's Mona Lisa, where he played as an ex-con who works as a chaperone for a call girl.

In 2012, Mr. Hoskins retired from acting shortly after he was diagnosed with Parkinson's disease. His last role was as one of the seven dwarves in that year's Snow White & The Huntsman.

Hear Carol's full interview with Nigel Cole to hear more remembrances about Mr. Hoskins.
